dialogues.text: They all got families to support.
Yeah. That's right, Jocko.  Those white guys sure shoot up at you like a yeast cake if you just cock an eye at them.
I guess you'll be making' some changes 'round here.
Nothin'. I just figure you were the right man for the job.
Hard to get up in the morning, huh?
That's right. How' you doin', Barney?
You know, man, that guy was trying to be friendly.
That ain't my idea of friendliness.
Like hell. You know, if you fellows stuck together 'stead of letting them walk all over you, they might not try it.
Cup of coffee.  I 'been meanin' to talk to you.
You know, over at the mill, there's just one guy that talked. It's kinda late to say it, but we shoulda acted different.
Been over to the other mill?
It's just that we're not used to seein' anyone stand up 'round here. Kinda took us by surprise.
Why don't you come over for a beer when you get through?
It's hard to know how to talk to the white folks these days.
It's a changing time. Sit down, son.
Well, it looks like we'll be getting our new school.
How come you all ain't sendin' them to the same school?
Well, you've got to go easy. We haven't had any trouble in town for eight years, and we're not going to have any now.
Can't live without trouble, can you?  Nice place you got here. Real nice.
Yes, the Lord's been pretty good to us. I guess you're a church man, aren't you?
Why? Don't you believe in the Lord?
Aw, I do. But 'seems to me us colored folks do a whole lot of church-goin'. It's the whites that need it real bad.
I think if you tried livin' in a town like this, instead of running free and easy, you'd soon change your tune.
I see.  Well, I guess we don't have much to say to each other.
And since we're talking, my wife and I don't want you hanging around our daughter.
Well, that figures.  Kind of fits in with everything else, don't it!
I know just how you feel, son. But believe me, you're going about it the wrong way.
Don't look like there's a right way.
Well, you have to be reasonable. Now they say you're a troublemaker. That's no good. Use a little psychology. Make 'em think you're going along - and get what you want.
You'll be in trouble, son.  Now just how do you intend to support your family?
I guess I'll rob a bank.
Don't you get smart with me, boy.
Oh yeah?  Seems to me, Reverend, you' more concerned 'bout your good. Guess it looks kind 'a bad, havin' me for a son-in-law.
You can be cocky now, boy. But you won't make it. You won't last. I just feel sorry for Josie. I knew it wouldn't work out.
Well, at least she ain't married to no white man's nigger! You been stoopin' so long, Reverend, you don't even know how to stand straight no more. You' just half a man!
Maybe I could talk to Bud Ellis. He might have a job for you at his filling station.
Nothing. Heard you were in town.
Wanted a look at your old man, huh?
Workin' a saw mill.  Here's to.
I said, I come to town with a girl.
Well, matter of fact, I done a lot of bangin' 'round.
Yeah. That's how me an' your mother got started. I'm tellin' you, boy, you ain't got a chance without dough. They take it all away from you.
Pretty good for a one-armed nigger, huh?
What d'you want anyhow? What you come and bother me for?
My son? I ain't got no son. You Duff?
What's the matter? Don't smell so good, huh? Must'a broken some records.
Couldn't get the words out before.
Better get him to a hospital.
Didn't I tell you to beat it - huh?
So you're courtin' the preacher's girl. Well, just watch your step, boy, or he'll preach you right into hell.  I'm counting on you, Reverend.
Wouldn't do for one of your people to sue at a time like this.
That'll make the folks very happy.
How often does he get like that?
Whenever he's got an edge on.
He's been hitting it pretty hard. Got high blood pressure, too. I guess it's hard on him, having you around.
Come back some other time, will you?
Nothing you can do. Been like this for days.
Want to come up the house? You can stay there till you get on your feet. There's no point paying a hotel.
It's just that I hate empty rooms.
Well, what're you going to do?
I guess I'll make me some trouble in that town.
I can always chop cotton if I have to.  If you want a ride, I'll take you home.
No, thanks. I'll take the bus.
Don't be too hard on him.
I know he wasn't much of a father.
Thanks, Duff. You' a nice guy. Not like Frankie.
Baby - want you to meet Duff.
What's the matter?! You mad at me?

Nothin'.  She's all right. Wouldn't have made it without her. Christ - haven't worked in eight months. Right now, I'm waitin' for some insurance money. And man, when I get it, I got plans to make me some more.  Let's get out'a here. This place gives me the willies.  You got some money?
What's the matter?! It's a celebration!
Your mother used to lay for her boss, boy. Did you know that?
Okay, so what's a girl supposed to do? Me not workin' and her cleanin' house for a white man. I'm tellin' you, boy, keep away from marriage. Ya gotta stay light on your feet or you won't make it.
Is she good in the hay? No point marryin' her just to find out. Is there, baby?
If you don't quit it, Will, I'm leaving.
You're breaking my heart.  Got to see a man about a dog.
Guess you must be lookin' after my boy. I'm Duff Anderson.
James Lee, you come in here and meet your daddy.
Ain't she goin' to take the boy?
She got herself a husband now. They don' want him 'round. And I tell you, man, I got no use for him neither.
Well, she never gave me none. Look, you better find him a place pretty quick.
I don't know. He's your boy.
I ain't so sure of that. If I was, maybe I'd feel different.
Yeah. Look, I'll be sendin' you the money from now on.
Make sure he gets those shots.
'That right? I thought he was up North.
You must be new in town.
I'll have me some of that punch there, too.
Haven't seen you around, have I?
Oh yeah? That's my home town.
No. My mother's dead.  You goin' back inside?
No. Never had much use for hell-howlers. You goin'?
Oh yeah? Well, I guess you got no choice.
Look, I don't know what you been told 'bout section gangs, but how 'bout seein' me sometime?
That's pretty good for a preacher's daughter.
You know, baby, I can't figure you out.
Why d'you come out with me? You slummin' or something?
So what you doin' with a cat like me in a joint like this?
You don't think much of yourself, do you?
Well, that's a funny thing to say.
You keep asking me why I'm here.
Yeah, and you keep not answerin', too.
I like a place with lots of life.
Go on - you can have one!
They must work on the section gang.
Well, they seem just like everyone else.
Hell, baby, I bet you think we got tails.
I guess it's hard working on the road like that.
Damn few places you can make eighty bucks a week.
I mean, you're kind of cut off, aren't you?
That's fine with me. Keeps me out of trouble.
Well, I don't get on so well most places.
I see. That beer made me dizzy.
Well, let's see now - not counting tonight ... must be about twenty-eight times.
You got a problem all right.
Well, my mother was the only good teacher the colored school ever had. Nobody bothers with those kids.
That's why you come back, huh?
It's hard to see any change. But I'm going to stay. Another year, anyway.
You got more guts than me, baby. It's a no-good town.
It's better than it used to be. Eight years ago they still had a lynching here. They tied a man to a car and dragged him to death. My father knew who did it, but he didn't say anything.
I get it.  Yeah, I can see your old man with a shot-gun right now.
But I would like to see you again.
You would, huh? If I was you, baby - I wouldn't go 'round stickin' out my jugular vein.
You almost got into trouble back there.
Hell, baby, I'm not in the third grade. Well, look - what' we gonna do next time -- have a nice long chat in the parlor?
Well, either we're gonna hit the hay or get married. Now you don't want to hit the hay, and I don' want to get married.
You have some very primitive ideas, don't you?
All right, so I'm primitive. So what d'you want with me?

Look, Duff - most of the men I know - they're kind of sad. When I met you the other day I had a feeling that you're different. That's why I went out with you. I thought we might have something to say to each other.
Hell, baby, I don't know what to say.
At first it was real strange. Hell, Japan is a long ways from Alabama. Really got under my skin, though. Almost didn't come back.
I don't know. 'Guess I belong here more than there.
Yeah. Knocked around for a couple of months after the Army. You been there?
Well, it ain't that good up there neither. Might as well make it here. 'Course I ain't really makin' it now.
Yeah. It's just like I figured.
Hell, I don't belong here. I don't know what I' been thinkin'.
Look, Duff - if you're free, I'm not working tomorrow.
Sorry, baby. I'm goin' to Birmingham.
I didn't know you had one.
No, I ain't married.  Well, good-bye.
I'm just going in to do my shopping.
Come here, Duff. No point running away from coincidence.
I ain't seen him in a couple of years.
You know, I been thinkin' - how 'bout us gettin' married?
Just what I said. Don't look so scared.
Look, baby - I don't know 'bout you, but it's the right thing for me. I just know it is. So, what d'you say?
Yeah. Wouldn't be no picnic for you. I ain't exactly housebroken.
She don't mean nothin' to me. That's all over.  Hell, baby - I'm askin' you to marry me. I guess you want a big scene, huh?
It's okay with me, baby. But how' you goin' to like it?
It'll be fine when we get done with it.
That's Bessie Hall. Barney works at the mill.
Hey, watch out! Guess you want a house full of pickaninnies too, huh?
That's all right with me. Always liked kids.
Let's just see how the two of us make out first, huh?
Smells like something crawled in there and died.
Oh really? I thought it was pretty good.
Duff - you know those women you used to know--
Am I as good as they?
Baby, you're the best thing that ever happened to me.
You still didn't answer my question.
Well, if you don't know I can't tell you.
My kids want me to teach them.
Like so. There you go. Okay, hit me!
I don't want to hurt you.
It sure scares you, a guy like that - settin' out on his porch, doin' nothin'. I seen hundreds of them - all my life.
My father's never done a thing for any of them.
How would you like to have a baby, Duff?
Ain't that something?!  That's just fine, baby.
Man, we sure hit the jackpot fast around here.
Well, he ain't mine, so skip it.
Hell, baby - I met this beautiful chick and she's just dyin' for me, okay?
Yeah. But just how're we goin' to make out? I got to get me a job.
Pay is so damn low. I don't want my kids to grow up like Barney's.
I'm telling you, baby, maybe we better get out of here.
We can always do that, Duff.
Yeah. Yeah, I know. I'm not really thinkin' about it. Anyway, don't want those white guys laughin' up their sleeve at me when they see me pull out.
Don't ask, baby - huh!  How much money you got with you?
Water pump's busted. I don't know if it's worth fixin', but I need that car.
You can have what I've got. It's right there.
You know - we do have enough money. Especially now.
Sure, baby. 'Fact, I don't ever have to work no more. When that baby comes, I can just stay home and send you back to school. How about that?
I could work even after the baby comes. A few hours a week, anyway.
What the hell could you do?
'You kiddin'? You ain't goin' to no white home. I seen the way they look at you when you go down the street.
I can't stand to see you like that. I know you can't help it.
How come you don't hate their guts?
I don't know. I guess I'm not afraid of them.
You were plenty scared that night in the car.
Just of getting hurt. They can't touch me inside.
Like hell they can't.  They can reach right in with their damn white hands and turn you off and on.
Not if you see them for what they are, Duff.
Jesus, baby, you're so full of talk! Well, you ain't never really been a nigger, have you - livin' like that in your father's house! So just shut your mouth.
Hell, if they don't blow up his place, they'll get him some other way. Don't make no difference no-how.
Nothin. Quit lookin' at me like that!
Well, that don't do me one bit of good!
Ain't you goin' to say something?
Well, that'll be the first time.
When I get set, I'll send for you.
You'll be better off without me. I ain't fit to live with no more. It's just like a lynchin'. Maybe they don't use a knife on you, but they got other ways.
You're not a man because of a job, Duff.
You don' know nothin' 'bout it, baby. Nothin'! And don't kid yourself - you did your bit.
Like I said, baby - I'll write you.
